channel.title: We need an argument
channel.description:
Here is the topic: People on the benefit (social welfare).
Should they have their benefit cut if they don't enrol their children with a preschool/school or GP?
Should they have the same rights as tax paying workers?
Do we need the beneficiaries to stay on the benefit in order to keep the world going?
Should they be sterilized during the time they remain on the benefit?

item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

When I was working a minimum wage job in a store, the best day for cigarette sales was when the welfare checks came out.

in canada welfare doesn’t give much money for drugs etc, instead they give very little spending money but they pay for your housing and food. Don’t get me wrong, it’s still abused. Most of the low rental housing are full of drunks and addicts, and they manage to get luxeries like satellite tv and the fastest internet plans. But the way I see it, even if they are too lazy or too fucked to work, either we throw em a bone or they end up on the street causing crime.

Then there is unemployment insurance which is for temporarily unemployed people. All workers pay into it, just a small fee from each pay (i think $1.70 from every 100 earned). If you are a seasonal worker (common in canada due to winter), laid off, pregnant, etc, you can receive up 55% of your wage as long as you are seeking employment in the case of a layoff etc. It’s a great system and even generates a surplus.

item.title: We need an argument
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Frell:

I already told you im only talking about illegal substances. You know, the ones that get expensive as fuck? The ones people steal money to pay for etc?

Nicotine addiction is pretty expensive too, and if you are aiming to prevent people from spending their welfare money on unnecessary products you’d better force them to pay for tobacco and booze with their own money.

Besides, I’m for welfare but it should be implemented in a way that rewards employment and discourages unemployment. This means lowering the welfare after a few months. For instance, in the Netherlands we have two ways of paying the unemployed. First, they can receive 70% of their last earned income for a maximum of 2 years. The duration is tied to how long you’ve been working before being fired. After that period ends, you still receive welfare but it’s barely enough to sustain a family. There is no money to spend on luxuries, and when your washing machine breaks down you’d better have a savings account because you won’t be able to finance it from your welfare.
